label: lecture 9 Greedy Algorithms.pdf
title: Principles of Greedy Algorithms and Activity Selection & The Knapsack Problems: Fractional and 0-1

questions.text: What is the fundamental core idea behind a Greedy Algorithm?

choices.label: It explores all possible solutions to find the global optimum.
choices.text: It explores all possible solutions to find the global optimum.

choices.label: It breaks the problem into overlapping subproblems and solves them bottom-up.
choices.text: It breaks the problem into overlapping subproblems and solves them bottom-up.

choices.label: It makes the locally optimal choice at each step in the hope of finding a global optimum.
choices.text: It makes the locally optimal choice at each step in the hope of finding a global optimum.

choices.label: It randomly selects a path and backtracks if the solution is invalid.
choices.text: It randomly selects a path and backtracks if the solution is invalid.

questions.explanation: Greedy algorithms make a locally optimal choice at every step with the goal of reaching a globally optimal solution, though this is not always guaranteed for all problem types.

questions.text: Which property is required to prove that a greedy algorithm yields an optimal solution?
questions.explanation: To prove a greedy algorithm works, one must typically demonstrate the Greedy Choice Property (a global optimum can be arrived at by selecting a local optimum) and Optimal Substructure.

questions.text: In the Activity Selection Problem, how should activities be sorted to apply the greedy strategy effectively?
questions.explanation: The standard greedy approach for the Activity Selection Problem is to sort activities by increasing finish times and select the first compatible activity.

questions.text: What is the time complexity of the `GREEDY-ACTIVITY-SELECTOR` algorithm if the input activities are already sorted by finish time?
questions.explanation: If the activities are already sorted, the algorithm simply iterates through the list once, resulting in a linear time complexity of O(n).

questions.text: Two activities $a_i$ and $a_j$ are considered compatible in the Activity Selection Problem if:

choices.label: The start time of one is greater than or equal to the finish time of the other.
choices.text: The start time of one is greater than or equal to the finish time of the other.

choices.label: The difference between their durations is minimal.
choices.text: The difference between their durations is minimal.

choices.label: They share the same resource at the same time.
choices.text: They share the same resource at the same time.

questions.explanation: Compatibility requires that the intervals $[s_i, f_i)$ and $[s_j, f_j)$ do not overlap, meaning $f_i \le s_j$ or $f_j \le s_i$.

questions.text: Which variant of the Knapsack problem can be solved optimally using a greedy strategy?
questions.explanation: The Fractional Knapsack Problem allows taking portions of items, which satisfies the greedy choice property. The 0-1 variant requires Dynamic Programming.

questions.text: What is the optimal greedy criteria for selecting items in the Fractional Knapsack Problem?

choices.label: Maximum value per unit weight ($v_i / w_i$)
choices.text: Maximum value per unit weight ($v_i / w_i$)

choices.label: Minimum value per unit weight ($v_i / w_i$)
choices.text: Minimum value per unit weight ($v_i / w_i$)

questions.explanation: To maximize the total value in a Fractional Knapsack, one should always prioritize items with the highest value-to-weight ratio.

questions.text:
Consider the following items for a Fractional Knapsack with Capacity W=50:
*   Item 1: $60, 10 lbs
*   Item 2: $100, 20 lbs
*   Item 3: $120, 30 lbs

What is the maximum value obtainable?
questions.explanation: Ratios: I1=$6/lb, I2=$5/lb, I3=$4/lb. Take all I1 (10lb, $60), all I2 (20lb, $100). Remaining cap: 20lb. Take 20lb of I3 (20 * $4 = $80). Total = $60 + $100 + $80 = $240.

questions.text: Why does the greedy strategy fail for the 0-1 Knapsack Problem?

choices.label: It is too slow to sort the items.
choices.text: It is too slow to sort the items.

choices.label: Choosing the best ratio locally may leave the knapsack with empty space that could have been better utilized by a different combination.
choices.text: Choosing the best ratio locally may leave the knapsack with empty space that could have been better utilized by a different combination.

choices.label: It violates the optimal substructure property.
choices.text: It violates the optimal substructure property.

choices.label: The problem size is usually too large for greedy algorithms.
choices.text: The problem size is usually too large for greedy algorithms.

questions.explanation: In 0-1 Knapsack, you cannot take fractions. A greedy choice might fill the bag such that the remaining space cannot accommodate other high-value items, resulting in a suboptimal total value compared to a combination found via DP.

questions.text: Which recurrence relation correctly represents the Dynamic Programming solution for the 0-1 Knapsack Problem?

choices.label: P(i, w) = max(v_i + P(i-1, w), P(i-1, w-w_i))
choices.text: P(i, w) = max(v_i + P(i-1, w), P(i-1, w-w_i))

choices.label: P(i, w) = v_i / w_i * P(i-1, w)
choices.text: P(i, w) = v_i / w_i * P(i-1, w)

choices.label: P(i, w) = max(v_i + P(i-1, w-w_i), P(i-1, w))
choices.text: P(i, w) = max(v_i + P(i-1, w-w_i), P(i-1, w))

choices.label: P(i, w) = min(P(i-1, w), P(i-1, w-w_i))
choices.text: P(i, w) = min(P(i-1, w), P(i-1, w-w_i))

questions.explanation: The value at step `i` with weight `w` is the maximum of either: not taking item `i` (inheriting `P(i-1, w)`) or taking item `i` (adding `v_i` to the optimal solution of the remaining weight `w-w_i`).
